metadata.title: CoS<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> nanowires supported graphdiyne for highly efficient hydrogen evolution reaction

Graphical abstract Planar unsaturated sulfurs in (211) facet of the CoS2 nanowires have been successfully activated through constructing Graphdiyne-CoS2 heterojunction nanocomposites as efficient electrocatalyst toward HER. Transition metal sulfides are an important category for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). However, only few edge unsaturated sulfurs functionalize as catalytic sites, which has dramatically limited the catalytic activity and stability. In this work, planar unsaturated sulfurs in (211) plane of the CoS2 nanowires have been successfully activated through constructing Graphdiyne-CoS2 heterojunction nanocomposites. The corresponding electrons transfer energy barriers for these planar unsaturated sulfurs have been significantly diminished, which are induced by the synergetic effects of the sp 1 hybridized carbons and unsaturated planar sulfurs. In addition, DFT simulations reveal the synergetic effects of the sp 1 hybridized carbons and unsaturated planar sulfurs can promote electron transfer kinetics of the key step, Volmer-Heyrovsky step, of the reaction. As expected, the Graphdiyne-CoS2 heterojunction nanocomposites exhibit superior HER catalytic performance with low overpotential of 97 mV at 10 mA cm−2, and the Tafel slope of 56 mV dec−1. Furthermore, the heterojunction shows outstanding stability as well due to the protection of the Graphdiyne (GDY). The approach thus paves the way for the further efficient transition metal disulfides catalyst manufactures. Keywords Graphdiyne Electrocatalysts Hydrogen evolution reaction DFT simulation 2D carbon material 1 Introduction The increasingly severe environmental situation has put forward higher requirements for renewable fuels. H2 is frequently advocated as a clean, renewable, high energy density energy carrier that has attracted widespread attention to optimize modern fossil fuels [1]. To utilize the abundant electricity generated by solar energy, wind power and nuclear power, developing efficient catalysts especially electrocatalysts has become the most critical and attractive research topic for promoting HER effectively [2–5]. To date, precious metal materials such as Pt, Ru and so on have shown high-performance in HER [6,7]. However, their low reserves have hindered extensive applications. The low cost transition metal sulfides (TMSs) have been widely used in HER [8–12], OER [13], overall water splitting [14,15], batteries [16,17]. Nevertheless, transition metal sulfides still suffer from several challenges in electrocatalytic HER application, such as lack of active sites, high Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption/desorption and poor eletrocatalytical stability, etc, which urgently require solutions. In order to overcome these problems, efforts have been devoted by the researchers recently. Xie et al. incorporated oxygen into MoS2 to construct edge-unsaturated coordinated sulfur atoms as active sites, resulting in an excellent electrocatalyst for HER [8]. In addition, they demonstrated nitrogen-anion modified CoS2/CC hybrid material can effectively improve the electrical conductivity and provide additional active sites for HER. In particular, the introduction of nitrogen in CoS2 greatly reduce the free energy for hydrogen adsorption on S and Co active sites, leading to superior performance [9]. Voiry's group constructed MoS2 at different temperatures to strip off part of the sulfur to build unsaturated coordinated Mo and sulfur vacancies, which led to improved hydrogen evolution activity [18]. In brief, applying chemical or physical modification strategies to design and synthesize inexpensive and efficient catalysts with fully exposed active sites and high conductivity for HER is of guiding significance [18–22]. GDY as a novel one-atom-thick, electron-rich, two-dimensional full carbon material [23–32], is composed of highly conjugated benzene ring (sp 2-C) carbon network and diacetylenic units (sp-C) connection, which was first successfully obtained via reasonable design by Li et al. [33–40]. Compared with graphitic carbon materials, GDY is an extraordinary carbon material because of its natural pores formed by the uniformly distributed triangular conjugated electron system. The large π-conjugated structure endows graphdiyne highly efficient charge carrier mobility (2 × 105 cm2 V−1 s−1) and large electronic conductivity (2.56 × 10−1 S m−1). Furthermore, GDY (0.47 eV) is recognized as a direct bandgap semiconductor which is different from graphene (0 eV) [33]. Prominent stability under acid or alkali conditions at as high as 150 °C, gives GDY superb chemical/physical properties [41–53]. As a superior material, GDY can be utilized in coating on numerous of nanomaterials to dramatically enhance conductivity and stability in electrochemistry [28,29]. GDY displays intrinsic superiority for constructing heterojunction structures [23,35]. Due to those unique advantages [54,55], GDY has been successfully applied in many fields, including water splitting (HER, OER, OWS) [56–58], ORR [59], sensors [52,53], lithium ion and solar cells [60–62], energy storage and related applications [63,64]. The uniform porous structure of the GDY system facilitates electron and hydronium diffusion/transfer in and out of the plane [65]. Further theoretical simulation reveals in the molecular and even atomic level the sulfur and carbon active sites are both important for efficient catalytic process [25]. Combining transition metal materials with GDY can enhance the conductivity of the heterojunction [31]. Simultaneously, GDY can act as an “electron reservoir” in the catalytic process, while, it has been proved that GDY can stabilize transition metals [24]. All of these provide theoretical and practical guidance for the improvement of electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts for HER through the combination of transition metal sulfides and GDY. Here, we demonstrated the synthesis of a new type of highly efficient and stable HER catalyst GDY/CoS2/CC (carbon cloth) by coating GDY nanowall over cobalt disulfide nanowire arrays through the in situ approach. In many reported transition metal sulfide materials, the main active sites are the unsaturated edge sulfur, which has the shortcomings of small quantity and difficult exposure. Our work has achieved a precise combination between the 2D (211) plane of CoS2 and the GDY plane, which provides much more active sites of carbon atoms and planar unsaturated S for synergistic catalysis. Due to the electron-rich nature of GDY, it can also enhance the electron transfer between the two-phase interface to improve their corporative catalytic effect. The results reveal the new GDY/CoS2/CC HER electrocatalyst exhibits much lower overpotential, higher catalytic current density and smaller Tafel slope (97 mV at 10 mA cm−2, 56 mV dec−1, respectively). Furthermore, the catalyst displays superior stability up to 36 hours, which is fatal important for further application. DFT simulations confirm that the introduction of GDY can dramatically accelerate the charge diffusion and transport at the interface, which also stabilizes the cobalt metal ions. Meanwhile, it supplies more active sites of carbon atoms and the unsaturated sulfur for facilitating hydrogen adsorption/desorption cooperatively, as well as, greatly decrease the reaction energy barrier for HER. Therefore, the in situ approach of incorporating GDY with CoS2 represents a novel way for improve the catalytic performance of plane activity of transition metal sulfides towards HER. 2 Results and discussion Synthesis and characterization of GDY/CoS2/CC As depicted in Scheme 1 , the synthesis process of the nanowire heterojunction GDY/CoS2/CC is accomplished in three steps. Fig. S1 shows the sample diagram at different stages of the synthesis process. Co(OH)F was hydrothermally synthesized on the pre-treated original CC (Fig. 1 a and S2) to produce Co(OH)F/CC composites (Fig. 1b and S3) [9]. Subsequently, Co(OH)F/CC was sulfurizedin atube furnace at 500 °C to yield CoS2/CC, which subsequently used as a template to be coated by GDY. The morphology of CoS2/CC was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (Fig. 1c and d) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (Fig. 1e–g), which show that the CoS2/CC nanowire arrays are completely independent of each other and cover the entire carbon cloth surface. After the Co(OH)F/CC precursor was vulcanized, nano-spherical protrusions appeared on the nanowire surface (Fig. 1d). This ordered 3D nanowire array of CoS2/CC with uniform micropores provides a high-quality substrate for the in-situ firm growth of GDY. The HRTEM image of GDY/CoS2/CC in Fig. 1k demonstrates the (211) plane of CoS2. After using in situ synthesis strategy to coat CoS2/CC with GDY, the entire 3D dimension CoS2 nanowire morphology structure remains intact, which is tiled with a dense and regular GDY nanowall (Fig. 1h). The package thickness of GDY coating on CoS2/CC can be clearly observed (Fig. 1i and j). The HRTEM of the CoS2 crystal plane under the GDY nanowall can be accurately captured, which is also the most solid evidence of the close combination of GDY and CoS2 (Fig. 1k). Fig. 1l–o display the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping images of the cobalt, sulfur elements of CoS2, carbon element of GDY, respectively, indicating the atomic distribution of these three elements in the whole nanowire. PXRD patterns of the prepared CoS2/CC and GDY/CoS2/CC are depicted in Fig. 2 a. The original CoS2/CC peaks can all be well assigned to the CoS2 phase. As for CoS2/CC, the recorded diffraction peaks at 27.8°, 32.2°, 36.2°, 39.8°, 46.3° and 54.8° are correspond to (111), (200), (210), (211), (220) and (311) planes of the CoS2 (JCPDS NO. 89-1492). Compared with the XRD diffraction pattern of pristine cobalt disulfide, the material of CoS2 coated by GDY exhibit obvious different diffraction peaks at 25.6° and 44°, which are the fingerprint peaks for GDY, suggesting that GDY has been coated on CoS2 successfully. Besides, the GDY/CoS2/CC catalyst shows gentle shift of the diffraction peaks to the larger angles compared with those of CoS2, which may be due to the strong interaction between CoS2 and GDY [25]. Raman spectra of the materials are also investigated to further study their phase compositions and microstructures. As shown in Fig. 2b, Raman spectrum of the synthesized GDY/CoS2/CC displays the characteristic peaks at 293 cm−1, 323 cm−1 and 393 cm−1, which match with the reported values for pristine CoS2 [17]. Besides, the other peaks observed in the Raman spectrum at 1376, 1586, 1933, and 2174 cm−1 are attributed to the D and G bands and vibration of conjugated diacetylene chain (–CC–CC–) for GDY, which are typical evidence of the successful preparation of GDY in the composite material. XPS further analyzed the physical and chemical characteristics of the samples. Fig. 2c shows the XPS spectra of the synthesized CoS2/CC and GDY/CoS2/CC, confirming the presence of Co, S and C elements in the sample. Compared with those of CoS2/CC, the obvious changes of the peak intensities for C and Co in GDY/CoS2/CC indicate that GDY has been successfully obtained and coated on CoS2. In addition, the peak of O element can be reasonably attributed to the absorption of O2 in the atmosphere. As presented in Fig. 2d, the two peaks at 779.2 and 794.0 eV can be attributed to Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2, respectively [16]. It can be subdivided into four peaks 778.9, 780.2, 793.9 and 795.7 eV, which can be attributed to Co3+ and Co2+, proving the coexistence of cobalt ions with different valence states. Fig. 2e exhibits five characteristicsignificantpeaksof CoS2 with the binding energy of 161.8, 162.8, 164.0, 168.8 and 169.9 eV, respectively. The first three peaks can be ascribed to S2− and S2 2−. Meanwhile, the other two peaks at 168.8 and 169.9 eV correspond to S 2p 3/2 and S 2p 1/2 of SO3 2− [16]. The XPS spectra of C 1s for GDY/CoS2/CC and GDY are given in Fig. 2f top and down, respectively, both of which show the peaks located at 284.6, 285.0, 286.7 and 287.7 eV corresponding to CC (sp 2), CC (sp), C–O and CO, respectively. Compared with the conventional GDY, the existence of a satellite peak at 290.0 eV in the spectrum of GDY/CoS2/CC (Fig. 2f) is due to the π–π* transition arising fromrestoration of the delocalized conjugatedstructure, highlighting the electronic interaction between GDY and CoS2. According to the above analysis, all these results of PXRD, Raman spectrum and XPS confirm the presence of the electron interactions between the CoS2 and GDY as GDYnanowallcoatingon CoS2, making GDY/CoS2/CC more favourable for electrochemical HER. In order to study the electrocatatytic activity and stability of the prepared GDY/CoS2/CC materials as working electrode for HER, a series of electrochemical experiments were studied in a three-electrode system with 1 M KOH as electrolyte. As displayed in Fig. 3 a, LSV curves of different materials for CC, GDY, CoS2/CC, Pt/C (20%) as well as our synthesized material GDY/CoS2/CC were recorded under the same condition at the scan rate of 2 mV/s. Among all samples, the GDY/CoS2/CC material showed the highest electrocatalytic HER activity at a potential of −0.6 V. At the same time, as the potential increased, the electrocatalytic current density of GDY/CoS2/CC was gradually higher than that of Pt/C, proving that GDY/CoS2/CC has well catalytic HER activity. In addition, as can be found in Fig. 3b, the GDY/CoS2/CC heterojunction can reach the current density of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 at the onset overpotential of 97 mV and 318 mV, respectively, which are both much lower than those of CoS2/CC (250 mV and 483 mV) and GDY (362 mV and 731 mV), indicating that GDY/CoS2/CC electrode shows more excellent electrochemical activity, which could be owning to the strong interactions between GDY and CoS2 confirmed by Raman and XPS spectrum, and the increase of active sites in the composites. Conventionally, kinetic parameter for HER in 1 M KOH can be evaluated by the Tafel slope value. What’s more, as Fig. 3c shown the Tafel plots for all the five kinds of electrodes, GDY/CoS2/CC (56 mV dec−1) is about 5 times smaller than that of CC (273 mV dec−1), also much smaller than that of pristine CoS2/CC (104 mV dec−1) and close to that of Pt/C. Besides, the calculated Tafel slope value of GDY/CoS2/CC is between the theoreticalVolmerTafel slope (118 mV dec−1) andHeyrovsky(39 mV dec−1) in base condition, which proves that the Volmer-Heyrovsky step determines the HER processing rate. To further investigate the reason of the high electrocatalytic activity of the GDY/CoS2/CC catalyst, the cyclic voltammetries of CoS2/CC and GDY/CoS2/CC were performed in the non-faradaic active region at the scan rate range of 10–100 mV/s (Fig. 3d and S4) to calculate the double-layer capacitance (C dl). Thereby, the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA = C dl/C s) could be estimated. The linear relationship between the scan rates and the current densities is displayed in Fig. 3e, indicating that the GDY/CoS2/CC electrode shows relatively high C dl (65.8 mF cm−2) after surface modification, which is about 1.3 times of CoS2/CC (50.3 mF cm−2), demonstrating that the introduction of porous GDY into the CoS2 material could effectively increase its active surfaces to promote the electrocatalytic activity for HER. Besides, comparing the LSV curves of nanowires with different diameters, the thinnest nanowire has an increased specific surface area and has better electrocatalytic performance (Fig. S5). Moreover, to assess the kinetics of the GDY/CoS2/CC material towards electrocatalytic HER, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded in alkaline solution (Fig. 3f) and fitted to the equivalent circuit model (Fig. S6) with the uncompensated solution resistance (Rs) and the charge transfer resistance (Rct). As the fitted parameters presented in Table S1, the GDY/CoS2/CC electrode material exhibits lower value of solution resistance (R s = 3.01 Ω) and lower charge transfer resistance (R ct = 11.03 Ω) than those of the other two types of electrodes, pristine CoS2/CC (R s = 3.15 Ω, R ct = 27.15 Ω) and GDY/CC (R s = 3.77 Ω, R ct = 542.6 Ω), indicating that GDY/CoS2/CC possesses the fastest electron-transport ability to enhance hydrogen evolution. Fig. S6 All of the above results further proves the superiority of the GDY/CoS2/CC electrode in HER, which is because the in-situ growth of GDY coating on CoS2/CC supplies more active surfaces and high electronic conductivity in the electrocatalytic process for HER. Then, the stability of GDY/CoS2/CC has been further studied by CV cycling and multi-level chronopotentiometry response tests. As illustrated in Fig. 3g and h, GDY/CoS2/CC electrode shows almost negligible degradation of current density after 6000 cycles tests, and the overpotential of sample for electrocatalysis exhibits very faint changes at the given current densities for nearly 36 hours, respectively, confirming the excellent stability of our synthesized material for electrocatalytic HER. These results confirm that our synthesized material GDY/CoS2/CC is much more stable for electrocatalytic HER than other transition metal materials (Table S2), which may because the great stable diacetylenic carbon material GDY on top of the whole CoS2 could effectively protect and stabilize it [24]. Furthermore, the direct growth of GDY on the high quality nanowire substrates CoS2 could avoid the usage of conventional adhesives, thereby subtly reducing the charge transfer-resistance between the phase interface and contact resistance, thus greatly improving the reaction kinetics. To gain further insights into the intrinsic activity of the designed composite GDY/CoS2/CC towards HER, density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been conducted. As displayed in Fig. 4 a, the composite model was constructed by covering the supercell CoS2 (211) surface slab with the graphdiyne layer including 24 Co atoms, 48 S atoms and 36 C atoms. According to the calculation results of the cobalt disulfide crystal plane (211) captured by HRTEM, it can be known that the crystal plane has two kinds of unsaturated coordination modes of sulfur active sites. Hydrogen adsorption and desorption on the surface of catalyst are the key processes during electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction [21,22]. Thus, to evaluate the HER kinetics of the GDY/CoS2/CC, the free energy of the HER process on the surfaces of CoS2 and GDY at all active sites were calculated. ΔG H of C-sites, S-sites and Co-sites in different coordination modes are presented in Fig. 4d–f, suggesting that C3 (ΔG H = 0.45 eV) and S2 (ΔG H = 0.44 eV) sites are the main active sites with the lowest Gibbs free energy for both hydrogen absorption and desorption. Thereby, coupling of GDY with CoS2 nanowire material could supply more active sites of carbon atoms in the acetylene bonds and the unsaturated sulfur in CoS2 for improving the intrinsic catalytic performance of catalytic hydrogen composite material, which may because of the strong electronic interactions between GDY and CoS2 confirmed by Raman and XPS spectrum. Moreover, the incorporation of the two kind of active sites could enhance the transformation of charges, leading to significant improvement of the catalytic activity for HER. As shown in the Fig. 4c, the contributions of all elements in density of states (DOS) were calculated, revealing that the GDY/CoS2/CC composite has very high conductivity, which should be due to the effectively incorporation of graphydine owning excellent electronic conductivity (2.56 × 10−1 S m−1) with CoS2 owning naturally metallic conductivity. As displayed in Fig. 4b, GDY could attract electrons from CoS2 and the electrons can be transferred freely between Co and S based on the well metallicity of cobalt disulfide. All these factors above could improve the intrinsic catalytic performance of the GDY/CoS2/CC composite and make it achieve remarkable catalytic performance for HER. Furthermore, the morphology and configuration of GDY/CoS2/CC catalyst after electrolysis test have also been evaluated. After electrocatalysis, we captured the CoS2 (211) plane again by HRTEM. By comparing the corresponding SEM and HRTEM images of GDY/CoS2 before and after the electrocatalysis, it is proved that the catalyst miantain its previous 3D nanowire structure and the morphology, as well as confirm the intact of the CoS2 (211) plane (Fig. S7). In addition, the PXRD patterns of the catalyst after electrocatalysis shows that the diffraction peak positions are consistent with those before catalysis, indicating that catalyst keeps high stability (Fig. S8). Besides, the full XPS spectra and High-resolution XPS spectra of Co 2p, S 2p and C 1s for GDY/CoS2/CC after the electrocatalysis are similar to those before catalysis, further demonstrating element content of the catalyst has not changed, and proving the stable existence of planar unsaturated sulfurs in (211) plane of CoS2 nanowires (Fig. S9). In according to the above findings, the outstanding electrocatalytic HER performance of the GDY/CoS2/CC nanocomposites could be attributed to the advantages of the heterojunction structure. Firstly, the heterojunction structure of the materials offers a route to enhance the electron and hydronium diffusion/transfer in and out of the plane to improve their corporative catalytic effect [65]. Secondly, owning to our achievement of the precise combination between the 2D (211) plane of CoS2 and the GDY plane, the heterojunction structure provides much more active sites of carbon atoms and planar unsaturated S for synergistic catalysis, as well as much higher electronic conductivity. Thirdly, the effect in-situ growth of the stable GDY coating on top of the whole CoS2/CC can effectively protect and stabilize the catalyst [24]. 3 Conclusion In summary, the innovation reveals the planar unsaturated sulfurs in these transition metal disulfides could be activated to functionalize as catalytic sites for HER, through novel materials engineering approach. Due to the electron transfer between different active sites, the resulting catalyst shows excellent catalytic activity (10 mA cm−2 at 97 mV). Our work describes the high performance of GDY functional materials and also provides new ideas for the design of subsequent materials. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal sulfides are an important category for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). However, only few edge unsaturated sulfurs functionalize as catalytic sites, which has dramatically limited the catalytic activity and stability. In this work, planar unsaturated sulfurs in (211) plane of the CoS2 nanowires have been successfully activated through constructing Graphdiyne-CoS2 heterojunction nanocomposites. The corresponding electrons transfer energy barriers for these planar unsaturated sulfurs have been significantly diminished, which are induced by the synergetic effects of the sp 1 hybridized carbons and unsaturated planar sulfurs. In addition, DFT simulations reveal the synergetic effects of the sp 1 hybridized carbons and unsaturated planar sulfurs can promote electron transfer kinetics of the key step, Volmer-Heyrovsky step, of the reaction. As expected, the Graphdiyne-CoS2 heterojunction nanocomposites exhibit superior HER catalytic performance with low overpotential of 97 mV at 10 mA cm−2, and the Tafel slope of 56 mV dec−1. Furthermore, the heterojunction shows outstanding stability as well due to the protection of the Graphdiyne (GDY). The approach thus paves the way for the further efficient transition metal disulfides catalyst manufactures.

coredata.dc:title: CoS2 nanowires supported graphdiyne for highly efficient hydrogen evolution reaction
